publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 92.51

seg.seg: ... still the ignorant fools mistreat him ...
... such strophes he spoke: this the Buddha let them know clearly ...
... who can remember [his earlier births], evokes the divine, clear sight and (make) disappear ...
...(if someone) should mistreat (this one) he will be thrown into a great hell. [41d] For if the one who does not behave morally ...
[Wenn] diesen[scil. den Traividya] einer verächtlich macht, so wird er in die große Hölle geworfen.
[If some]one ridicules this one [i.e. Traividya], he will be thrown into the great hell.
... great (Arhats). If one goes forever to see the great householders, he will have to give up the fervor of monks ...
... he trusts. And if he had to speak a lie and the untruth or gossip, for the sake of food he says anything ...
... (he will go) (after)wards to hell. [43d] These ones who [only] went half from the house to the Buddha from a poor ...
... to the other births, mingling only with householders, to the towns ...
... some were angry out of envy for benefactors, houses and possessions ...
... is sick, others are in distress. If he comes (to see?) those, [46b] ...
... because, (when) he acquires possessions, (he finds?) in this existence enemies without number ... [46d] ...
... (many enemies he finds here,) the monk, who always wears the monk's robe, when going into the town as an acquirer
... [47d]. Having realized this terrible error [and] the great danger of veneration and reverence
... in poor condition. Evoke satiation of possession, (you give)an opportunity to the enemies [48d]
... you found pleasure, you could not become satiated, but now you have gone from the house
... [49d] ... The almsround [is] for living, not for invitations ... seeking ...

p.note: This leaf includes strophes 39b-50a of the first part of the Satkāravarga (XIII); thus, from 39b-46a (i.e. to the second line of the verso page), its contents are identical to those of , a6-b8. The metre is 21/21/18/13 syllables (rhythm: ab: 8/7/6, c: 9/9 or 4/5/4/5, d: 7/6). Lines b4-5 contain remnants of a translation of Uv 13.15-13.16.
Badly damaged fragment, including approximately a third of a leaf, right side.
It is no longer possible to read entseño mäntañye as indicated in the transliteration by 69.
It is no longer possible to read yaṃ as indicated in the transliteration by 69.
It is no longer possible to read 47 as indicated in the transliteration by 69.

list.item:
Transliteration

b1. It is no longer possible to read entseño mäntañye as indicated in the transliteration by [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 69.
b2. It is no longer possible to read yaṃ as indicated in the transliteration by [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 69.
b5. It is no longer possible to read 47 as indicated in the transliteration by [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 69.

General remarks

This leaf includes strophes 39b-50a of the first part of the Satkāravarga (XIII); thus, from 39b-46a (i.e. to the second line of the verso page), its contents are identical to those of [[THT 31]], a6-b8. The metre is 21/21/18/13 syllables (rhythm: ab: 8/7/6, c: 9/9 or 4/5/4/5, d: 7/6). Lines b4-5 contain remnants of a translation of Uv 13.15-13.16.

a1 /// _k_arsormeṃ : appamā_t\ yamaskent_r_a [mā =yśeñca]ñ\ [a] a2 /// [sa toṃ] weña ślokanma : te śārsa-me pudñäkt= ānai – a3 /// [k_use] campn ·pyac kalatsi : ñäkcye pilkw āstreṃ erṣt_r_a _ṣ_p_a nau_t_a a4 /// – mt_r_a appamā_t\ wroc[c]e lupṣt_r_a nraisa 40-1 k_use no su tākaṃ apā[ṣ]tte a5 /// wr[occeṃ :] kattāk[e]ṃ ksa yaṃ lkātsi ṣe_k\-ṣe_k\ tārkaṃ spelke ṣa[mā] a6 /// – §kt_r_a §: §wai§ke §wa§ṣe §_ṣ_p_a §_k_a§sko§r wa§_t\ §we§ntsi §kli§nne §po §[w]e§·ṃ – a7 /// – s·ṃ n[r]aintane 40-3 ṣeṃ ywārc os[t]meṃ [l]·[e] – pudñäkte_ś\ [s]·ai[ce] – a8 /// [cm]ela [t]riwo[_ṣ\] att[s]ai (– – – –) [m]p= e[ṣe] : rinne – – – b1 /// ostwasa ekñinta (– – – –) [_m_a] – ñy·nt_r_a – – – b2 /// t_s\ alā_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ alyaik kekm·_ṣ\ ·y[āts]·ne c[e]ṃ yaṃ – – – b3 /// no _k_alpā_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ ekñinta : ce cmelne sanaṃ snai keśä\ – – – – b4 /// _ṣ_ṣ_aṃ [_k_a]rstoṣ wastsi ṣe_k\ ausu rīne ymai ṣamāne : _k_alp· – b5 /// – – ce nāky empelye _k_arsormeṃ yarke ynāñ_m_aññentane orotsai pro b6 /// s[n]ai[cc]ene ykene : persa_t\ soylñe ekñesa sanaṃ_t_s\ laute b7 /// nta swā_r_aṣṣa_t\ mā soytsi cämpyā_s_a : ñake n= ostme· la·[o] b8 /// ·[ä]n_t\ pintwā_t\ śaitsisa mā ka[k]onta te – – rīta – –

a1 /// #M21_21_18_13# kärsormeṃ : #39c appamāt yamaskenträ ; mā aiśeñcañ|=yśeñcañ a a2 /// sa ; toṃ weña ślokanma : #40b te śārsa-me , pudñäkt= anaiśai|ānai(śai) a3 /// k_use ; campn (e)pyac kalatsi : #41a ñäkcye pilkw āstreṃ , erṣträ ṣpä ; nautä a4 /// (yā)mträ appamāt , orocce|wrocce lupṣträ nraisa 41 #41d k_use no su tākaṃ , apāṣtte ; a5 /// orocceṃ|wrocceṃ : #42b kattākeṃ ksa yaṃ lkātsi ṣek , -ṣek tārkaṃ spelke ṣamā a6 /// (pa)kträ : #43a waike waṣe ṣpä , käskor wat ; wentsi klinne , po we(ṣṣä)ṃ ; – a7 /// (po)s(tä)ṃ nraintane 43 #43d ṣeṃ ywārc ostmeṃ l(tw)e(ṣ) , pūdñäkteśc|pudñäkteś ; s(n)aice – a8 /// cmela ; triwoṣ attsai(k , kattākeṃ)mp= eṣe : #44c rinne – – – b1 /// ostwasa ; ekñinta(sa , entseño) ; mä(nta)ñy(e)nträ – – – b2 /// ts alāṣṣäṃ alyaik kekm(o)ṣ (ñ)yāts(e)ne ceṃ yaṃ – – – b3 /// no ; kälpāṣṣäṃ ekñinta : #Xx ce cmelne sanaṃ , snai keś – – – – b4 /// ṣṣäṃ kärstoṣ wastsi ṣek ausu ; rīne ymai ṣamāne : #Xx kälp· – b5 /// (47) #47d ce nāky empelye , kärsormeṃ ; yarke ynāñmäññentane ; orotsai pro b6 /// snaiccene ikene|ykene : #Xx persat soylñe ekñesa sanaṃts laute b7 /// nta swāräṣṣat ; mā soytsi cämpyās|cämpyāsä : #Xx ñake n= ostme(ṃ) la(ts)o b8 /// (49) #49d ·änt pintwāt śaitsisa mā kakonta te – (:) #50a rīta – –
Badly damaged fragment, including approximately a third of a leaf, right side.

a4 [Wenn] diesen[scil. den Traividya] einer verächtlich macht, so wird er in die große Hölle geworfen. 463

a1 ... still the ignorant fools mistreat him ... a2 ... such strophes he spoke: this the Buddha let them know clearly ... a3 ... who can remember [his earlier births], evokes the divine, clear sight and (make) disappear ... a4 ...(if someone) should mistreat (this one) he will be thrown into a great hell. [41d] For if the one who does not behave morally ... a5 ... great (Arhats). If one goes forever to see the great householders, he will have to give up the fervor of monks ... a6 ... he trusts. And if he had to speak a lie and the untruth or gossip, for the sake of food he says anything ... a7 ... (he will go) (after)wards to hell. [43d] These ones who [only] went half from the house to the Buddha from a poor ... a8 ... to the other births, mingling only with householders, to the towns ... b1 ... some were angry out of envy for benefactors, houses and possessions ... b2 ... is sick, others are in distress. If he comes (to see?) those, [46b] ... b3 ... because, (when) he acquires possessions, (he finds?) in this existence enemies without number ... [46d] ... b4 ... (many enemies he finds here,) the monk, who always wears the monk's robe, when going into the town as an acquirer b5 ... [47d]. Having realized this terrible error [and] the great danger of veneration and reverence b6 ... in poor condition. Evoke satiation of possession, (you give)an opportunity to the enemies [48d] b7 ... you found pleasure, you could not become satiated, but now you have gone from the house b8 ... [49d] ... The almsround [is] for living, not for invitations ... seeking ...
